FIELD NOTES: SEABIRDS IN ANCIENT GREECE

field notes

birds

I was sent on a trip to Ancient Greece recently. I can‚Äôt disclose too many details publicly, but I arrived in the summertime, which is the perfect time of year to be watching for seabirds in Greece. It‚Äôs very difficult to collect any usable data for research during non-Watcher missions, but I was at least lucky enough to get some birdwatching in in the two days that I was there, and I was even able to speak to a few gulls‚Äîseveral Chroicocephalus ridibundus, to be precise!

I made a list of seabirds that I was able to identify.

SPECIES COUNT NOTES
Chroicocephalus ridibundus 27 I saw a lot of them, and they are supposed to be common this time of year, but the number is probably skewed by the fact that I was offering them food.
Ichthyaetus melanocephalus 20 They seem to be a good deal smaller than their modern counterparts? Might be imagining it. Didn‚Äôt have anything to measure with.
Haematopus ostralegus 18 Lovely, noisy guys. I saw a bunch smashing open molluscs along the shores.
Larus cachinnans 15 I saw one catch a whole ground squirrel. Good job!
Ichthyaetus audouinii 13 Even before everything on Earth happened, these guys were a vulnerable species for quite some time. It‚Äôs nice to see that that wasn‚Äôt always the case, though.
Sterna hirundo 12 These guys really will just make their nests anywhere, huh‚Ä¶
Gelochelidon nilotica 12 Lovely specimens with their summer black caps and bills!
Sternula albifrons 11 Their common name is ‚Äúthe little tern.‚Äù Suits them.
Hydroprogne caspia 8 Huge guys! Spotted a few pairs mixed in with other species‚Äô colonies.
Thalasseus sandvicensis 7 Saw a few hunting!
Chroicocephalus genei 4 These are relatively uncommon birds!!! Not sure if I was lucky, or if they were more common in antiquity. Faintly pink breast! It‚Äôs summertime alright!
Ichthyaetus ichthyaetus 1 It‚Äôs not winter yet. What are you doing here??? Huge guy. Wasn‚Äôt expecting to see one all the way out here.
Gelochelidon nilotica (?) 5 But I‚Äôm listing these ones separately down here because I wasn‚Äôt quite confident that I properly distinguished them from juvenile Thalasseus sandvicensis‚Ä¶
Thalasseus bengalensis (?) 3 Saw a few diving for fish while out on the sea, though I was a little busy at the time with other tasks to look too closely.

I wish I‚Äôd had more time to examine the birds‚Äîmany gulls reach maturity in about 4 years, so 3 millennia is nearly enough time for 750 generations! I wonder how much has changed since?
